channel.title: NYT > World News
channel.copyright: Copyright 2022 The New York Times Company

item.title: Saskatchewan Stabbings Suspect Found Dead, Canada’s Police Say
item.description: The body of a man being sought by the authorities was found with wounds that were not believed to be self-inflicted. The killing of 10 people stunned the country.
item.dc:creator: Ian Austen and Dan Bilefsky
item.media:credit: Amber Bracken for The New York Times
item.media:description: Two officers investigating a home on Monday in Weldon, Saskatchewan, where an older man who was believed to be a victim of the mass killing lived.

item.title: Shelling Cuts Off Outside Power to Ukrainian Nuclear Plant
item.description: The Zaporizhzhia plant is now using one of its own reactors to power critical cooling systems. The Moscow-backed authorities in the southern Ukrainian region of Kherson offered conflicting statements about whether a vote on joining Russia would be held as planned.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times
item.media:credit: Jim Huylebroek for The New York Times
item.media:description: A man reviewing damage outside a clinic in Mykolaiv, Ukraine, on Monday after an overnight rocket attack.

item.title: Typhoon Live Updates: Hinnamnor Slams Into South Korea
item.description: The storm will linger over the southern part of the nation Tuesday, bringing record winds and dumping as much as 24 inches of rain on some parts of the country.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times
item.media:credit: Chang W. Lee/The New York Times
item.media:description: Strong waves in Busan, South Korea, on Monday. Typhoon Hinnamnor made landfall on Tuesday morning.

item.title: Liz Truss to Replace Boris Johnson as Prime Minister
item.description: Britain’s Conservative Party members chose Ms. Truss, the hawkish foreign secretary, over Rishi Sunak, the former chancellor of the Exchequer. She takes over a country in serious economic crisis.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times

item.title: Of Barbecues and Men: A Summer Storm Brews Over Virility in France
item.description: A Green politician told men to get over meat and masculinity for the sake of the planet, setting off a sizzling argument.
item.dc:creator: Roger Cohen
item.media:description: Sandrine Rousseau, a member of parliament from the Greens, has thrust barbecue to the center of French debate.

item.title: In Somalia, ‘Famine Is at the Door,’ U.N. Warns
item.description: A U.N. official stopped short of officially declaring a famine in the country. But some aid workers said that the threshold had already been reached.
item.dc:creator: Abdi Latif Dahir
item.media:credit: Malin Fezehai for The New York Times
item.media:description: A settlement for displaced people in Doolow, in Somalia’s southern Gedo region, in May. A severe drought has left half the country’s population in need of food assistance.

item.title: Strong Earthquake Shakes Southwestern China
item.description: State media said more than 40 people were killed, but communications in the landslide-prone area were disrupted and the full damage was unclear.
item.dc:creator: Keith Bradsher
item.media:description: A road in China’s Sichuan Province after an earthquake on Monday, in a photo from the Chinese news agency Xinhua.

item.title: China Imposes More Covid Lockdowns, Stoking Anxiety
item.description: Nearly every province has recorded infections in recent days, leaving some 60 million residents locked down. Weariness is growing by the day as the restrictions go on seemingly without end.
item.dc:creator: Vivian Wang
item.media:description: A testing site in Chengdu, China, on Friday, during a lockdown. The city’s testing system collapsed over the weekend, leaving residents waiting in line for hours.

item.title: Chile Voters Reject New, Left-Leaning Constitution
item.description: The rejected constitution would have legalized abortion, adopted universal health care and enshrined more than 100 constitutional rights, a global record.
item.dc:creator: Jack Nicas
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.media:credit: Tomas Munita for The New York Times
item.media:description: Celebrating the rejection of the proposed constitution in Santiago, Chile, on Sunday.

item.title: Kenya’s Supreme Court Upholds Presidential Election Results
item.description: In a sweeping rejection of claims that the Aug. 9 vote had been rigged, the court confirmed Vice President William Ruto as the country’s fifth president.
item.dc:creator: Declan Walsh and Abdi Latif Dahir
item.media:description: Supporters of President-elect William Ruto celebrate in the streets of the informal settlement of Mathare in Nairobi, Kenya, on Monday.

item.title: Blame, Hate and License Plates in a Divided Kosovo Town
item.description: Tensions between ethnic Albanians and ethnic Serbs have flared in recent months, stoked by a bureaucratic dispute over vehicle tags, testimony to the region’s toxic identity politics.
item.dc:creator: Andrew Higgins
item.media:credit: Armend Nimani for The New York Times
item.media:description: The Serbian flag in the ethnically Serb northern part of Mitrovica, Kosovo. Violent ethnic animosity has largely subsided, but tensions are bubbling up again.

item.title: Trial Over 2016 Terror Attack in Nice Opens in Paris
item.description: A self-radicalized Tunisian man plowed a truck through crowds celebrating Bastille Day, killing 86. The proceedings, against eight defendants, are scheduled to last until December.
item.dc:creator: Constant Méheut
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.media:description: The truck used in the 2016 attack in Nice, France. The driver was killed by the police. Those facing trial are accused of being indirect accomplices.

item.title: Live Updates: One Suspect in Canada Stabbing Is Dead, the Police Say
item.description: The other of the two suspects, who the police say are brothers, is still at large.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times

item.title: Hamas Executes 5 Palestinians in Gaza, Officials Say
item.description: The Gaza Interior Ministry said that three of the executions were carried out by hanging and the other two by firing squad.
item.dc:creator: Patrick Kingsley
item.media:description: The executions were the first reported in Gaza in a half-decade and occurred amid anxiety within Hamas.

item.title: Ukraine Nuclear Plant Disconnected From Grid After Shelling
item.description: A fire caused by shelling forced the staff of Europe’s largest nuclear plant to disconnect from the nation’s power grid, showing that risks remained at the plant despite the presence of U.N. experts.
item.dc:creator: Marc Santora, Ivan Nechepurenko and Matthew Mpoke Bigg
item.media:description: A motorcade transporting the International Atomic Energy Agency expert mission arriving at the Zaporizhzhia power plant last week.

item.title: Liz Truss to Replace Boris Johnson at a Time of Crisis for Britain
item.description: Ms. Truss, who prevailed over Rishi Sunak, will be greeted by an array of vexing problems, including double-digit inflation, a looming recession, labor unrest and soaring household energy bills.
item.dc:creator: Mark Landler and Stephen Castle
item.media:description: Liz Truss at the Conservative Party headquarters in London on Monday after it was announced that she had prevailed in the contest to be Britain's next prime minister.

item.title: Russia Sentences Journalist Ivan Safronov to 22 Years in Prison On Treason Charges
item.description: The prosecution of Ivan Safronov, a former defense reporter, sent chills through the Russian journalism community.
item.dc:creator: Ivan Nechepurenko and Alina Lobzina
item.media:description: Ivan Safronov denied allegations that he had disclosed state secrets and refused to enter a plea deal.

item.title: Breaking Taboo, Germany Extends Life of 2 Nuclear Reactors
item.description: The step is intended to cushion a growing energy crisis in Europe but could upend the country’s plans to become the first industrial power to shutter its program.
item.dc:creator: Erika Solomon and Melissa Eddy
item.media:description: The Isar 2 nuclear power plant in Essenbach, Germany.

item.title: 50 Years After Attack at Munich Olympics, a Formal German Apology
item.description: Palestinian militants killed 11 Israeli athletes at the Olympic Games in 1972. Decades later Germany asked the victims’ families for forgiveness for not keeping the delegation safe.
item.dc:creator: Christopher F. Schuetze
item.media:description: Pictures of the victims of the massacre at the 1972 Olympics in Munich at a ceremony on Monday to commemorate the 50th anniversary of the attack, which left 11 Israeli athletes and a German policeman dead.

item.title: Horror grips a bucolic farming region after the killing spree.
item.description: Police searches and the roar of helicopters disrupt the routine in a rural stretch of Saskatchewan.
item.dc:creator: Dan Bilefsky and Vjosa Isai
item.media:credit: Heywood Yu/The Canadian Press, via Associated Press
item.media:description: An investigator in protective equipment worked at a crime scene in Weldon, Saskatchewan, on Sunday.

item.title: Israel Says Shireen Abu Akleh Most Likely Shot by Israeli Soldier
item.description: The Israeli Army has concluded that Shireen Abu Akleh, a Palestinian-American broadcaster, was probably killed by one of its own soldiers — but stopped short of accepting definitive blame.
item.dc:creator: Hiba Yazbek and Patrick Kingsley
item.media:credit: Samar Hazboun for The New York Times
item.media:description: The site where Shireen Abu Akleh, a Palestinian-American journalist, was shot and killed in the West Bank town of Jenin.

item.title: Suicide Attack Hits Russian Embassy in Afghanistan, Killing 2 Employees
item.description: The bombing in Kabul, which also left 4 Afghan civilians dead, was the first strike on a diplomatic mission since the Taliban regained control.
item.dc:creator: Christina Goldbaum
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.media:description: A Taliban fighter outside the Russian Embassy in Kabul, Afghanistan, after the attack on Monday. The blast was the latest in a steady drumbeat of suicide bombings in the country in recent months.

item.title: Museums in the U.S. and Europe Are in Blockbuster Mode
item.description: From Los Angeles to Antwerp, Jason Farago, our critic at large, picks a fall season laden with offerings on Cubism, modern Korean art and paintings of the Spanish Baroque.
item.dc:creator: Jason Farago
item.category: Los Angeles County Museum of Art
Cubism and the Trompe lOeil Tradition (Exhibit)

item.title: Rising Energy Prices and High Inflation: The Economic Issues Facing Liz Truss
item.description: Consumer prices in Britain are rising at their fastest pace in decades, as the inflation rate exceeds 10 percent and is expected to keep climbing.
item.dc:creator: Eshe Nelson
item.media:description: The Bank of England is forecasting a long recession to begin later this year as wages lag and household budgets are squeezed.

item.title: As U.K. Prime Minister, Liz Truss Will Face Hard Times
item.description: Coming to power during the worst economic crisis since the Thatcher era, Liz Truss will need all her ideological dexterity — some call it opportunism — to succeed.
item.dc:creator: Mark Landler
item.category: Elizabeth II, Queen of Great Britain
item.media:description: Liz Truss in London on Monday after it was announced she had won the contest to become Britain’s next prime minister. Colleagues speak of her nerve, drive and appetite for disruptive politics.

item.title: The Fall Dining Scene
item.description: Diners are returning from their summer vacations and heading back into restaurants.
item.dc:creator: Priya Krishna

item.title: The candidates sought to channel an icon of the right: Margaret Thatcher.
item.dc:creator: Mark Landler and Stephen Castle
item.media:credit: Hilaria McCarthy/Daily Express/Hulton Archive, via Getty Images
item.media:description: Britain’s former prime minister, Margaret Thatcher, in 1982. Both Rishi Sunak and Liz Truss have tried to mimic the ethos and politics of the former leader.

item.title: With Boris Johnson’s departure, Ukraine loses a friend.
item.description: If there is one place where appreciation for Mr. Johnson is undimmed, it is Ukraine, where he has been seen as a genuine friend since Russia’s invasion in February.
item.dc:creator: Megan Specia
item.media:description: Prime Minister Boris Johnson of Britain and President Volodymyr Zelensky of Ukraine in Kyiv last month.

item.title: The Hunt for Big Hail
item.description: Hailstones of record size are falling left and right, and hailstorm damage is growing. But there is surprisingly little research to explain why.
item.dc:creator: Oliver Whang
item.media:description: A supercell thunderstorm threatening to engulf a barn near Imperial, Neb., in 2019. Almost all hail is created in supercells, or storms with updrafts of rising air that slowly rotate.

item.title: Javier Zamora Carried a Heavy Load. He Laid it to Rest on the Page.
item.description: Decades after traveling without his parents from El Salvador to the U.S. as a 9-year-old — a journey that almost killed him — Zamora describes the experience in a memoir.
item.dc:creator: Benjamin P. Russell
item.media:credit: Cassidy Araiza for The New York Times
item.media:description: “I don’t expect the people who are in the book to read it. But my dream scenario is that they open it,” Zamora said, “and see that there is this book out there thanking them.”

item.title: How Was Britain’s Prime Minister Elected?
item.description: Around 160,000 people had the final say in choosing the leader of the Conservative Party, and therefore the next prime minister.
item.dc:creator: Megan Specia
item.media:description: 10 Downing Street, the prime minister’s official residence in London.

item.title: Rishi Sunak was seen as Boris Johnson’s likely successor. Then the campaign began.
item.dc:creator: Stephen Castle

item.title: A prolonged leadership contest has come down to two sometimes bitter rivals.
item.dc:creator: Mark Landler
item.media:description: Rishi Sunak and Liz Truss, the candidates vying to succeed Prime Minister Boris Johnson, campaigning on Wednesday in London.

item.title: Liz Truss has offered tax cuts, but stayed quiet on efforts to tackle a mounting economic crisis.
item.dc:creator: Mark Landler, Stephen Castle and Peter Robins
item.media:description: Ms. Truss was greeted last month by Nadhim Zahawi, the chancellor of the Exchequer, and supporters in Birmingham.

item.title: Shakespeare or Bieber? This Canadian City Draws Devotees of Both
item.description: For nearly 70 years, Stratford, Ontario, has attracted legions of theater fanatics to its Shakespeare festival. About a dozen years ago, a very different type of pilgrim began arriving: Beliebers.
item.dc:creator: Vjosa Isai
item.media:credit: Brett Gundlock for The New York Times
item.media:description: A cutout of Justin Bieber in the Stratford Perth Museum. The setting is meant to replicate the steps of the city’s Avon Theater.

item.title: Climate Change Is Ravaging the Colorado River. There’s a Model to Avert the Worst.
item.description: Success in the Yakima River Basin in Washington holds lessons for the seven states at war over water in the American West.
item.dc:creator: Henry Fountain and Ruth Fremson

item.title: Typhoon Hinnamnor: South Korea Braces for Storm’s Arrival
item.description: The storm, expected to make landfall on Tuesday, could be the strongest in the country’s recorded history. Japan and China were also making preparations.
item.dc:creator: Jin Yu Young and Mike Ives
item.media:credit: Yonhap, via Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: High waves hit the southern coast of Jeju Island, South Korea, on Monday as the typhoon approached.

item.title: Your Monday Briefing
item.description: Support for European energy costs.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost

item.title: The suspects are likely in the city of Regina, police chief says.
item.dc:creator: Víctor Manuel Ramos
item.media:credit: Heywood Yu/The Canadian Press, via Associated Press
item.media:description: One of the sites of a stabbing in Weldon, Saskatchewan. Police say the suspects have fled to Regina, about 300 kilometers south of Weldon.

item.title: Ukrainians in Rural Ireland Piece Together New Lives, Step by Step
item.description: With 50,000 Ukrainians now finding sanctuary in Ireland, the largest number of refugees the country has ever accepted is merging with locals in homogeneous rural villages.
item.dc:creator: Megan Specia
item.media:credit: Paulo Nunes dos Santos for The New York Times
item.media:description: A Ukrainian woman minding a child at a hostel that hosts Ukrainian families on Arranmore Island, Ireland.

item.title: Vietnam’s Plan for Loudspeaker Broadcasts Meets Resistance
item.description: The city of Hanoi may revive regular loudspeaker broadcasts, which were routine before most people had TVs or internet access. Residents are wary of bringing them back.
item.dc:creator: Chau Doan and Mike Ives
item.media:credit: Linh Pham for The New York Times
item.media:description: Loudspeakers in front of shops in Hanoi, Vietnam, late last month.

item.title: Your Monday Briefing: Europe’s Energy Protections
item.description: Plus Chileans vote on a new constitution and rickshaws lead India’s electric vehicle transition.
item.dc:creator: Amelia Nierenberg
item.media:description: Pipes at the landfall facilities of the ‘Nord Stream 1’ gas pipeline in Lubmin, Germany, in March.

item.title: Thirteen ships carrying grain set sail, the largest convoy so far.
item.dc:creator: Carly Olson
item.media:credit: Jim Huylebroek for The New York Times
item.media:description: The port of Odesa on the Black Sea in Ukraine on Monday.

item.title: Europe’s Leaders Vow Economic Relief, Fearing Unrest
item.description: Germany, Sweden and the Czech Republic announced measures to populations feeling the bite of rising inflation and energy costs tied to war in Ukraine.
item.dc:creator: Erika Solomon
item.media:description: A protest in Prague on Saturday against the Czech government and its response to the energy crisis.

item.title: John Sullivan, the U.S. Ambassador to Russia, Leaves Moscow to Retire
item.description: John Sullivan managed the U.S. embassy during its most difficult period in decades — when Moscow forced hundreds of employees to leave and after Russia invaded Ukraine.
item.dc:creator: Edward Wong
item.media:description: John J. Sullivan served as deputy secretary of state in the Trump administration before being appointed ambassador to Russia in December 2019.

item.title: Deadly shelling in the east offers a grim reminder of a continuing battle.
item.dc:creator: Matthew Mpoke Bigg
item.media:description: Ukrainian firefighters at the site of a missile strike in Kramatorsk, in the eastern Donetsk Province.

item.title: Other European nations try to fight rising prices as fears of social unrest grow.
item.description: Sweden, Germany, and the Czech Republic all announced new measures, while soaring energy prices and inflation stoked protests in Prague.
item.dc:creator: Erika Solomon and Liz Alderman
item.media:description: Protests in Prague on Saturday underlined concerns that the energy crisis and soaring inflation could trigger instability in Europe.

item.title: Germany Announces $65 Billion Relief Package Amid Soaring Inflation
item.description: Berlin aims to ease the burden on citizens facing soaring inflation and surging energy costs that have worsened with Russia’s invasion of Ukraine.
item.dc:creator: Erika Solomon
item.media:description: Chancellor Olaf Scholz of Germany, at a news conference on Sunday, promised that “no one will be left behind” as soaring costs hurt consumers.

item.title: Office Drama
item.description: Labor Day has become a flash point for big companies who want workers to return to the office.
item.dc:creator: Ian Prasad Philbrick
item.media:credit: Aaron Wojack for The New York Times
item.media:description: Credit Karma requires their employees to work part of the week in person, but allows them to pick which days.

item.title: Russia’s Unfounded Claims of Secret U.S. Bioweapons Linger On and On
item.description: Without providing evidence, the Kremlin is pressing allegations that the U.S. operates labs in Ukraine and beyond. This week, it has called an investigative session in Geneva.
item.dc:creator: Steven Lee Myers
item.media:description: President Vladimir Putin of Russia at a student event last week. The Kremlin accuses the United States of operating secret biological research programs to wreak havoc around the globe.

item.title: In South Korea, a Hit Show Brings Autism Into the Spotlight
item.description: “Extraordinary Attorney Woo” has raised awareness of autism in South Korea, where developmental disabilities are still a taboo subject for many people.
item.dc:creator: Jin Yu Young
item.media:credit: Chang W. Lee/The New York Times
item.media:description: Teaching a child at Autism Partnership Korea, a center for young children with autism in Seoul.

item.title: How Russia Relies on Old Tech in Weapons Aimed at Ukraine
item.description: Investigators who examined the electronics in Russia’s newest cruise missiles and attack helicopters were surprised to find decades-old technology reused from earlier models.
item.dc:creator: John Ismay

item.title: China Threatens Reaction After U.S. Announces Arms Sales to Taiwan
item.description: A $1.1 billion package would “severely jeopardize” ties, Chinese officials say in demanding that Washington revoke the deal.
item.dc:creator: Alexandra Stevenson
item.media:credit: Lam Yik Fei for The New York Times
item.media:description: Taiwanese soldiers during a live-fire drill in Pingtung, Taiwan, last month. The Biden administration just approved the sale of more than $1.1 billion worth of arms to Taiwan.

item.title: A 9-year-old boy is killed in a rocket attack in southern Ukraine.
item.dc:creator: James C. McKinley Jr.
item.media:description: Trails left by Russian rockets could be seen from the northeastern Ukrainian city of Kharkiv on Saturday.

item.title: Renewed Shelling Puts Ukraine’s Zaporizhzhia Nuclear Plant at Risk
item.description: The decision to keep monitors at the plant despite the obvious risks underscored what the International Atomic Energy Agency’s leader called the “unprecedented” peril of the moment.
item.dc:creator: Marc Santora and Andrew E. Kramer
item.media:credit: Jim Huylebroek for The New York Times
item.media:description: A delegation from the International Atomic Energy Agency, returning from an inspection of the Zaporizhzhia nuclear power plant, at a Ukrainian-controlled checkpoint.
